content: The Act is titled the "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" and includes definitions for various terms. The "Senior Investor Protections Enhancement Act of 2009" defines "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older and "securities laws" as specific acts related to securities. The Act also amends Section 2(a) of the Securities Act of 1933. The Securities Act of 1933, Securities Exchange Act of 1934, and Investment Company Act of 1940 have been amended to define "senior" as an individual aged 62 or older. The Investment Company Act of 1940 and Investment Advisers Act of 1940 have been amended to define "senior" as an individual who is 62 years of age or older. The Securities Act of 1933 is amended to include a special rule for seniors, allowing the Commission to impose a civil penalty of up to $50,000 for violations directed towards or committed against seniors. Directive to the United States Sentencing Commission. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend the Federal sentencing guidelines to ensure appropriate punishment for violations of securities laws against seniors. This includes applying specific guideline offense levels to offenses where seniors are victims. The Federal sentencing guidelines are to be reviewed and amended to punish securities law violations against seniors, ensuring consistency with other directives and statutory provisions. Changes will be made to meet the purposes of sentencing outlined in the law.
